properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall combined with strong northerly winds are causing blizzard conditions. Conditions should improve beginning this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A developing low pressure system will bring heavy snow to northern Alberta, beginning late this morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected. Snow will taper off Tuesday overnight, as the low pressure system moves eastward into Saskatchewan. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T03:24:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T11:25:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1962319791.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected overnight and Wednesday. Snow squalls are expected to develop overnight and continue into Wednesday. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible by Wednesday evening. Northwest winds gusting to 50 km/h will also combine with the freshly fallen snow to produce blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to gradually weaken Wednesday night. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. A brief period of heavy snow and reduced visibility is then expected late this morning or early this afternoon as a cold front moves through the area. Additional snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are possible by this evening. Snow at times heavy will make travel hazardous due to reduced visibilities. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected for southwestern Nova Scotia tonight and Wednesday with lesser amounts elsewhere. Total snowfall: up to 10 cm from Yarmouth County to Queens County, with 2 to 5 cm expected for Lunenburg County and the Halifax region and lesser amounts further to the east. Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia from the Yarmouth area up to the Halifax area. Time span: this evening until Wednesday morning. Remarks: this snowfall event has the potential to create difficult driving conditions in some areas during the Wednesday morning commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T06:45:37-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A low pressure system will give 10 cm of snow over Fort Nelson and Muncho Lake - Stone Lake today. Snow will begin this morning and intensify in the afternoon. The heavy snow will ease late this afternoon in Muncho Lake and in the evening in Fort Nelson as the low moves into Alberta. The heaviest snow for the Fort Nelson region will be near and north of Fort Nelson, particularly towards the Northwest Territories border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Further snowfall amounts: generally 5 cm except locally 10 to 15 cm or more over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland. Time span: today. Remarks: While the setup for intense snow squalls is less favourable today than it was on Monday, snow and strong westerly winds continue to give blizzard conditions in many areas this morning. Conditions will slowly improve as the winds start to subside during the day today and more so tonight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T22:59:45-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A warm front and associated low pressure centre just north of Haida Gwaii has moved inland this morning. About 20 cm of snow has fallen overnight near Kitimat to Terrace. As the warm air moved onto the coast, snow changed to freezing rain and will change to rain showers shortly. At Stewart, precipitation is expected to remain as snow and taper to flurries, or showers as the system moves inland this afternoon. A further 5 to 10 cm of snow is forecast. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T21:29:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T14:19:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1287662433.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace, North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A building surface ridge of high pressure will give strong winds near the Richardson Mountains today. Strong easterly winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will cause blizzard conditions with near zero visibility. Winds will ease somewhat this evening and become intermittent. Local blowing snow is still possible near the Richardson Mountains tonight through Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T04:50:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T12:51:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2118674790.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong Pacific frontal system is moving through the BC coast. The front will stall over northern Vancouver Island on today before shifting southward on Wednesday. This storm is forecast to bring widespread heavy rainfall to the west coast of Vancouver Island. For Tofino and communities further north such as Zeballos and Tahsis, heavy rain is expected for today and tonight. As the front begins to move southward early Wednesday, heavy rain will start to impact communities south of Tofino. Total rainfall amounts in the range of 100 to 150 mm can be expected for this event. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-18T04:49:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-17T12:50:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1115218247.2019
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold with wind chill near minus 40 will persist in parts of east-central Saskatchewan for a few hours before cloud cover moves in, moderating temperatures. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T22:24:06-00:00

Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A low pressure system will give 10 cm of snow over Fort Nelson and Muncho Lake - Stone Lake today. Snow will begin this morning and intensify in the afternoon. The heavy snow will ease late this afternoon in Muncho Lake and in the evening in Fort Nelson as the low moves into Alberta. The heaviest snow for the Fort Nelson region will be near and north of Fort Nelson, particularly towards the Northwest Territories border. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
